The "Federal Employees Life Insurance Improvement Act" may be cited as the short title. A study and report on certain life insurance options offered to federal employees is required. The Office of Personnel Management must conduct a study on life insurance options for Federal employees and submit a report to Congress by July 31, 1998. The study includes surveying Federal employees' interest in group universal life insurance, group variable universal life insurance, and additional voluntary accidental death and dismemberment insurance. Additionally, the report will contain comments, analysis, and recommendations from the Office of Personnel Management on these options. SEC. 3. REPEAL OF MAXIMUM LIMITATION ON EMPLOYEE INSURANCE. Amends Chapter 87 of title 5, United States Code to remove the maximum limitation on employee insurance. 

SEC. 4. FOSTER CHILD COVERAGE. Amends Section 8701(d)(1)(B) of title 5, United States Code to include coverage for foster children.

SEC. 5. INCONTESTABILITY OF ERRONEOUS COVERAGE. SEC. 5. INCONTESTABILITY OF ERRONEOUS COVERAGE. Amends Section 8706 of title 5, United States Code to protect the insurance of an employee under a policy purchased under section 8709 from being invalidated due to erroneous coverage, even if discovered after 2 years of coverage. Chapter 87 of title 5, United States Code is amended to allow employees with insufficient pay to continue insurance by paying withholdings into the Employees' Life Insurance Fund. Employees with insufficient pay can continue optional insurance by paying withholdings into the Employees' Life Insurance Fund, as allowed by the amendments to Chapter 87 of title 5, United States Code. Employees with insufficient pay can continue optional insurance by paying withholdings into the Employees' Life Insurance Fund, as allowed by the amendments to Chapter 87 of title 5, United States Code. This provision allows employees to maintain optional life insurance on family members by arranging to pay an amount equal to the required withholdings through the agency or retirement system administering their pay, annuity, or compensation. SEC. 7. ADDITIONAL OPTIONAL LIFE INSURANCE CONTINUATION AND PORTABILITY. Employees can continue optional insurance by paying withholdings into the Employees' Life Insurance Fund, allowing them to maintain optional life insurance on family members. Employees can continue optional insurance by paying withholdings into the Employees' Life Insurance Fund. The amount of additional optional insurance can be continued, with or without reduction, based on the employee's written election at the time eligibility arises. If the employee elects to have withholdings cease, the amount of additional optional insurance will be reduced by 2 percent each month after turning 65 and retiring or receiving compensation. The employee can choose to continue optional insurance by having withholdings from their annuity or compensation. If no election is made, the employee will be treated as if they chose to have the insurance stop after 50 months. If an employee initially elects to continue optional insurance but later cancels, the insurance amount may be reduced. An employee can choose to continue optional insurance by electing to do so under conditions set by the Office of Personnel Management. This allows them to maintain a portion of their insurance for a specified period at group rates, even if they are not eligible to continue under certain circumstances. The employee can continue optional insurance by electing to do so at group rates set by the Office of Personnel Management. The insurance amount will be reduced by 50% at age 70 and will stop at age 80, with provisions for extension or conversion to an individual policy. Alternatively, the employee can choose to reduce or stop the insurance at any time. The employee can continue optional insurance by electing to do so at group rates set by the Office of Personnel Management. The insurance amount will be reduced by 50% at age 70 and will stop at age 80, with provisions for extension or conversion to an individual policy. No election for additional optional insurance can be made 3 years after the effective date, and all additional optional insurance for former employees will terminate after that, with provisions for temporary extension and conversion to an individual policy. The Office of Personnel Management will submit a report to Congress on optional insurance provided under title 5, United States Code. The report will include recommendations on continuation, extension, or permanency of the insurance. Additionally, a technical amendment is made to section 8714b(d)(1) of title 5, United States Code. Improved optional life insurance on family members is addressed in Section 8. Section 8714c(b) of title 5, United States Code is amended to provide optional life insurance on family members for eligible employees in multiples of 1, 2, 3, 4, or 5 times the specified amounts for a spouse and each child. Employees can adjust or cancel coverage at any time. Technical and conforming amendments are also made to the code. The optional life insurance coverage for family members under Section 8714c(b) of title 5, United States Code can be adjusted or canceled at any time. Amendments are made to provide coverage in multiples of 1, 2, 3, 4, or 5 times the specified amounts for a spouse and each child. Additionally, amendments are made to address the continuation of full cost after the former employee turns 65 years old if an election under this section remains in effect. Beginning 180 days after enactment, the Office of Personnel Management will offer an 8-week open enrollment for chapter 87 of title 5, United States Code. Employees can elect group life insurance without evidence of insurability and adjust optional life insurance for family members. SEC. 10. MERIT SYSTEM JUDICIAL REVIEW. Amends Section 7703 of title 5, United States Code, to extend the deadline for filing appeals to 60 days. Effective immediately upon enactment and applies to pending or new cases. SEC. 11. EFFECTIVE DATES. The amendments made by this Act will take effect on the date of enactment. Section 3 will be effective on the first day of the first pay period after enactment. Section 5 applies to cases of erroneous coverage after enactment. Section 6 will be effective on the first day of the first pay period after enactment. Section 7 will take effect on the first pay period after the 180th day following enactment. Following the date of enactment of this Act, the Office of Personnel Management may prescribe a date at least 60 days after enactment. Regulations will allow employees to continue optional insurance without reduction if they retired before the effective date and maintained insurance as per previous regulations. Additionally, there are improvements to optional life insurance for family members. The amendments for improved optional life insurance on family members will take effect on the first day of the first pay period after the 180th day following the enactment of the Act. Any employee election under section 9 and withholdings will be effective on the first day of the pay period occurring 365 days after the election period, following a pay period where the employee was in a pay and duty status.
